Soil Type: Average, medium, well-drained soils, tolerates clay.  Adaptable to a wide variety of soils, as long as it is well-drained.
When to Divide: Do not divide, long tap root, but may self-seed in optimum growing conditions.
Habit: Height:  12"-36" with flower stalk, Spread:  12"-18, bushy, vase-shaped habit.
Something Special or Unique: It is a high nectar producer, and grows in a range of soils.  Native Americans applied it to open wounds, and wildlife loves the proteinaceous seeds.  This legume (or pea-family plant) fixes nitrogen in the soil.  It is drought resistant and native to North America.  Dalea is a superfood for the Rusty-Patched Bumblebee, which is listed as endangered.  It is also a host plant for the larvae of the Dogface Sulphur (common in New York) and Reakirt's Blue.  This plant blooms heavily for four weeks in June and continues to bloom sporadically until September.  It needs support in its first year because it uses most of its energy developing a long taproot (a mature plant's taproot will be 5.5-6 feet) which will later allow it to become drought resistant.  Leaves can be used for tea, and roots are palatable.

Soil Type: Evenly moist, humusy, well-drained.  Avoid poorly-drained or wet soils, especially in winter.
Habit: Height:  8"-18" with flower stalk, Spread:  8"-12", Basal rosette.

Soil Type: Ensure the ground is well-drained (on a hillside or in a raised bed at least 1ft tall).  Medium moisture, well-drained soils are preferred.  Drought tolerant.

Habit: Height: 6"-12" (cut back by 1/3 to encourage new growth and maintain height), Spread: 12"-36”, Groundcover

Make sure to plant it either on a hillside or in a raised bed of at least 1ft to ensure that the ground is well-drained enough.  This is a very early bloomer, so the bees love coming to its flowers just as they awake.  For cold climates, mulch in winter to minimize sun scorch and dessication.

Soil Type: Moist humus soil, tolerates clay, needs constant moistness
When to Divide: In spring when shoots are 1” high
Habit: Height:  12” (24-36” with flower stalks) Spread:  12-18” Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Tolerates wet soil, good next to ponds, does well with mulching, tolerates black walnut trees

Soil Type: Moist, well-draining soil, mulched
Habit: Height:  12” Spread:  8” Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Looks lush all season from May until heavy frost; used in teas, ice cream, soup.  Ruffle its leaves and release its scent to repel gnats and mosquitoes.

Soil Type: Dry, well draining
Habit: Height: 24”, Spread: 8”, Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Native to the Northeast US, need air circulation to prevent powdery mildew, good mildew resistance

Soil Type: Dry, well draining
Habit: Height: 24”-36", Spread: 12”, Clumping
Something Special or Unique: A hybid of the native Bee Balm with shades of pink and blue flowers, needs air circulation to prevent powdery mildew, some mildew resistance

Soil Type: Well-draining; drought resistant
Habit: Height:  24” (36” with flower stalk) Spread:  12”-24” Clumping, occasionally reseeds.
Long Lived or Short Lived: 5 years or longer; Occasionally reseeds in undisturbed ground.
Something Special or Unique: Ornamental, not edible; attracts cats; does not spread by rhizome; self seeds very lightly

Zone: Not winter hardy; may bring in for winter
Soil Type: Well-draining and fertile
Habit: Height:  24” Spread:  Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Use in pie, salads, replacement for cinnamon; remove flowers to continue leaf growth; flowers are edible

Zone: Not winter hardy; may bring in for winter
Soil Type: Well-draining and fertile
When to Divide: Prefers no division, can collect seeds
Habit: Height:  24” Spread:  Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Use in salads, anywhere you use lettuce leaves (wraps, sashimi wraps); remove flowers to continue leaf growth; flowers are edible

Zone: Not winter hardy; may bring in for winter
Soil Type: Well-draining and fertile
Habit: Height:  24” Spread:  Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Use in Key-Lime Cheesecakes or as a replacement or addition to lime in cooking.  Strong lime scent and flavor.

Zone: Not winter hardy; may bring in for winter
Soil Type: Well-draining and fertile
Habit: Height:  24” Spread:  Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Strong Italian, classic basil scent.  Use in salads, pizzas, and Italian dishes, anywhere where you would use the classic basil.

Zone: Not winter hardy; may bring in for winter
Soil Type: Well-draining and fertile
Habit: Height:  24” Spread:  Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Italian, classic basil scent.  Use in salads, pizzas, and Italian dishes, anywhere where you would use the classic basil.

Zone: Not winter hardy; may bring in for winter
Soil Type: Well-draining and fertile
Habit: Height:  24” Spread:  Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Use in Thai dishes, curries, coconut-based soups; clove flavor; remove flowers to continue leaf growth; flowers are edible

Zone: Not winter hardy; may bring in for winter
Soil Type: Well-draining and fertile
Habit: Height:  24” Spread:  Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Its name, Akoko Mesa, means Chicken Dance in Ghana because it is used for preparing poultry.  It has also been used for hundreds of years in dishes and medicinal preparations.

Zone: Not winter hardy; may bring in for winter
Soil Type: Well-draining and fertile
Habit: Height:  24” Spread:  Clumping
Scent: Fragrant, peppery, with a hint of vanilla
Something Special or Unique: Blue Spice is a peppery basil with vanilla scent.  It can be used in place of allspice in dishes like pumpkin pie.  It does not taste like the traditional basil, and should not be used the same way.

Zone: Not winter hardy; may bring in for winter
Soil Type: Well-draining and fertile
Habit: Height:  24” Spread:  Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Minette is prized for its miniature leaves and small stature.

Zone: Not winter hardy; may bring in for winter
Soil Type: Well-draining and fertile
Habit: Height:  24” Spread:  Clumping
Something Special or Unique: This has a classic basil scent and dark purple leaves.

Zone: Not winter hardy; may bring in for winter
Soil Type: Well-draining and fertile
Habit: Height:  24” Spread:  Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Romanesco is a classic Italian basil with strong flavor.

Zone: Not winter hardy; may bring in for winter
Soil Type: Well-draining and fertile
Habit: Height:  24” Spread:  Clumping
Something Special or Unique: This basil has a classic Italian flavor, with unique ruffled, deep purple leaves.

Soil Type: Any soil, Drought resistant, Well draining
Habit: Height:  6” Spread: 12” Spreading by rosette, very slowly
Scent: Sweet and strong in early evening and early morning
Something Special or Unique: Large 3” flowers. Seeds can be collected and started in trays and transplanted.

Soil Type: Dry to medium water, must have well-draining soil
Habit: Height:  4” Spread:  trailing Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Herb used with chicken, pork, salads

Soil Type: Fertile well-draining soil
Habit: Height:  6” Spread:  6” Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Herb used with italian seasoning, chicken, and pasta

Where to Grow: Sunny windowsill or shady outdoor spot for the summer
Soil Type: Fertile, well-draining, moist soil
When to Divide: Resents division.  Each bulb is one plant and cannot be divided.
Habit: Height:  6-8” Spread:  6-12”, Mound forming
Something Special or Unique: This shamrock has brilliantly pink flowers with dark red crosses on their leaves.  Its growth may be minimal in the winter and it may even go dormant, but it will come back up in the spring.  Prefers reverse osmosis or dehumidifier water (needs acidic water, and city tap water tends to have basic water).

Soil Type: Organically rich, fertile, medium moisture, well-drained soils; will perform well with average soils if well-drained
Habit: Height: 24"-36", Spread: 18"-24", Mounding
Something Special or Unique: Its long leaves appear bristly, but are not.  This poppy is one of the few that has a deep red flower.

Soil Type: Fertile well draining
Habit: Height: 6” (12” with flower stalk), Spread: 6”, Clumping, occasionally reseeds

Soil Type: Fertile, loamy, and well-draining soil
Habit: Height: 6", Spread: 6", Rosette forming
Long Lived or Short Lived: Short lived (2-3 years) but seeds can be collected
Something Special or Unique: Each flower has sterile stamen with a tuft of small hairs, giving it the name "beardtongue".

Soil Type: Well draining, drought resistant
Habit: Height: 24” (36” with flower stalk), Spread: 12”-24”, Clumping, occasionally reseeds
Something Special or Unique: Dark purplish foliage that fades to green as the summer progresses.
Images: Penstemon digitalis 'Husker Red':Penstemon digitalis 'Husker Red' Seedling

Soil Type: Average to moist soil, with these conditions, tolerant of many soils.
When to Divide: Do not divide.  Collect seeds, refrigerate and germinate, and transplant when small.
Habit: Height:  Up to 24", Spread:  8", single stalk
Something Special or Unique: Good cut flower.  Its common name, balloon flower, refers to how its flowers are shaped before fully opening
Images: Platycodon grandiflorus 'Hakone Blue':Platycodon grandiflorus 'Hakone Blue' Seedling

Soil Type: Light, mediudm moisture, organically rich, well-drained, loamy soils.
When to Divide: Do not divide.  Collect seeds, refrigerate and germinate, and transplant when small.
Habit: Height:  6"-12", Spread:  6"-8", single stalk
Something Special or Unique: Good cut flower.  Its common name, balloon flower, refers to how its flowers are shaped before fully opening

Soil Type: Average to moist soil
Habit: Height:  12-18” (24” with flower stalk) Spread:  12”-18” Clumping, occasionally reseeds.
Something Special or Unique: Dark purplish foliage that fades to green as the summer progresses; tolerates black walnut trees

Soil Type: Average to moist soil
Habit: Height:  12-18” (24” with flower stalk) Spread:  12”-18” Clumping, occasionally reseeds.
Something Special or Unique: Green foliage with light purple flowers; tolerates black walnut trees.  Its flowers are especially fragrant.

Soil Type: Average to well-draining; drought resistant
Habit: Height:  12-18” (24” with flower stalk) Spread:  12”-24” Clumping, occasionally reseeds.
Something Special or Unique: May rebloom in fall, good for borders and rock gardens

Soil Type: Average to well-draining; drought resistant
Habit: Height:  12-18” (24” with flower stalk) Spread:  12”-24” Clumping, occasionally reseeds.
Something Special or Unique: May rebloom in fall, good for borders and rock gardens
Images: Potentilla atrosanguinea var. argyrophylla:Potentilla atrosanguinea var. argyrophylla Seedling

Where to Grow: Dappled sun, morning sun, afternoon shade.  Prefers semi-shade.
Soil Type: Likes clay.  Ammending soil with compost, bone meal fertilizer, or peat moss improves the growth.  Does not like boggy winter soils.
When to Divide: Easily divided every few years.  Plant roots 1" below soil.  Eaily propagated by root cuttings.
Habit: Height:  6" Spread:  12"
Something Special or Unique: Flowers emerge pink or violet, but change to blue as they age.  They retain their foliage until late winter, making them almost evergreen.  If it's too hot, it will go dormant and reappear as it cools near fall.  Classified as "Endangered".
Images: Pulmonaria officinalis ssp. obscura:Pulmonaria officinalis ssp. obscura Seedling

Where to Grow: Full sun to part shade, best flowering in full sun
Soil Type: Average, dry to medium, well-drained soils
Habit: Height: 12"-36", Spread: 12"-36", Rhizomatus
Something Special or Unique: Native to the Eastern United States, can be used as a honey plant

Soil Type: Average, well-draining, medium moisture; prefers clay or sand soils; will tolerate poor, dry soils
When to Divide: Do not divide.  Can collect seeds and grow plants as starters for propagation.
Habit: Height: 3'-5', Spread: 18”-24”, Clumping
Resists: NOT RESISTANT; make sure to fence the first year
Maturity Rate: Will bloom second or third year
Something Special or Unique: They're sometimes called the "Mexican Hat" because their flowers look like a slender sombrero.  They may need staking the first or second year.  These plants are often used in sunny borders, native plant gardens, meadows, and prairies.  They should be massed, with 3-5 plants per clump due to their narrow stature and sparse leaves.  Native to the Eastern United States and Ontario.

Soil Type: Average, well-drained, rocky soil.  Does best in a rock garden.
When to Divide: Take cuttings in early spring and root in water or a damp paper towel.
Habit: Height: 6”-12”, Spread: 12"-24”, Mounding
Something Special or Unique: Native plant.  It is both a culinary herb and medicinal plant for the rock garden.

Soil Type: Well-draining; drought resistant
Habit: Height: 12” (24” with flower stalk), Spread: 12”-24”, Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Very long blooming, low maintenance, low water requirement second year.  Native to New York.  Rabbits and deer nibble in spring, but plants recover.
Images: Rudbeckia fulgida var. sullivantii:Rudbeckia fulgida var. sullivantii Seedling

Soil Type: Well-drained soil, moderately fertile.  Dry to medium water requirements, will tolerate drought, dry soil, and shallow, rocky soil.  Must be sharply-draining.
When to Divide: Do not divide, but can propagate by seed or cuttings
Habit: Height: 24”-36”, Spread: 24"-36”, Mounding
Something Special or Unique: Has light blue-green foliage with some yellow edges to the leaves.  Flowers are toxic in large quantities.  Mulch in northern zones.  Prune plants back to old wood in early spring.  Do not ingest.  For the rock garden.  Host plant to Swallowtail Butterflies.

Soil Type: Any soil, but must be well draining; drought resistant
When to Divide: Rosettes can be removed in early spring
Habit: Height: 18”, Spread: 18”, Clumping
Long Lived or Short Lived: 3 years in soggy ground or shade; otherwise very long lived
Something Special or Unique: Difficult to grow from seed.  Will flower late first year, and return strong next year. Remove spent flowers to promote reblooming

Where to Grow: Full to part sun.  Does not tolerate shade.
Soil Type: Tolerates sandy, medium, clay soils with little nutrition.  Does not like to be fertilized, drought tolerant, will tolerate moist soil.
When to Divide: Divide clumps in spring by gently teasing apart roots
Habit: Height:  24" Spread:  12" Clumping
Maturity Rate: Blooms first year at the end of the season.
Something Special or Unique: Young leaves are excellent in salads and soups.  Do not eat during pregnancy.  Grows well with Lamb's Ears

Soil Type: Well-draining, normal to sandy, infertile soil; drought tolerant
Habit: Height:  6-8” (8” with flower stalk) Spread:  12” Clumping.
Long Lived or Short Lived: Long lived; short lived in soggy soil
Something Special or Unique: Sheer after flowering to tidy; evergreen, good ground cover

Soil Type: Will grow in clay soils, but must be well-draining.  Drought resistant once established.  Needs care for first two years.
When to Divide: Do not divide.  Collect seeds, refrigerate until February, soak with warm (100F) water for 24 hours and start indoors.  Transplant outdoors when 4-6" high.
Habit: Height:  12" Spread:  12" Habit:  Hairy, fluffy clumps.
Something Special or Unique: Roots are medicinal.  Do not cut back in fall, cut back in spring instead.  Mulching is recommended for Zones 4 and 5

Soil Type: Well draining soil, drought resistant, no fertilizer needed, water only when soil is chalky dry
Habit: Height: 4”, Spread: Sprawling
Something Special or Unique: Evergreen, good in containers, rock walls, crevasses, as groundcover; good for draping over edges of pots, rocks or steep hillsides

Soil Type: Dry, average to medium soil must be well-drained; drought resistant
When to Divide: This plant does not spread easily and would not appreciate division.  To propagate, collect seed and direct-sow.
Habit: Height: 6-12" (18-24” with flower stalk) Spread: 6-12”, Upright
Something Special or Unique: Native plant.  Not very agressive, and very small plant with humble foliage.  This is a compact, low-growing, non-agressive goldenrod.  Its genus name references the medicinal healing properties of some species.

Soil Type: Dry soil, low fertility, drought resistant
When to Divide: Early spring; when rosette has several small roots, cut rosette free with scissors
Habit: Height: 4-6” (18” with flower stalk) Spread: 6-12”, Spreading; produces rosettes
Something Special or Unique: Tolerates black walnut trees

Soil Type: Moist but well-draining, does not like water-logged winter soils
When to Divide: Divide spreading clumps in spring; when rosette has several small roots, cut rosette free with scissors
Habit: Height:  12" Spread:  12"
Something Special or Unique: Tolerates black walnut

Where to Grow: Full shade outdoors; eastern or western window, does not like direct sunlight
Soil Type: Well draining, low fertility, drought resistant
When to Divide: When a shoot has at least six leaves, cut it from the main plant with a clean scissors.  Then, place the stem in a glass of water and plant it in soil once roots have formed.  If there are leaves that have fallen off the plant, those can be laid on top the soil until they root.
Habit: Height: 2-12”, Spread: 4”, Clumping, rosette forming, groundcover
Something Special or Unique: Only likes to be watered about once per month, likes to thoroughly dry out between waterings.  Grows roots during the winter, mostly dormant during the summer.  Best to transplant in September after blooming.

Soil Type: Clay, tolerates most soils
When to Divide: Collect seeds in Fall for next year, and store at room temperature.
Habit: Height: 6"-12", Spread: 6", Clumping, occasionally reseeds
Something Special or Unique: Long blooming, pinch young plants for bushier growth.  Good in containers

Soil Type: Well-draining; drought resistant
Habit: Height:  12” (36” with flower stalk) Spread:  12” Clumping.
Something Special or Unique: Cut back after flowering for additional bloom. Unlike its invasive relatives, this species does not spread aggressively by self-sowing or rhizome

Soil Type: Average, medium, well-drained soil.  Tolerates full sun if the soils are kept moist.  Likes moist soils along streams, woodland gardens, or ponds.
When to Divide: Divide clumps early spring or summer
Habit: Height:  36" Spread:  12"
Something Special or Unique: Flowers are three inches across.  Likes to be grown near water.

Soil Type: Moisture retentive, drought resistant
When to Divide: Divide in spring.  Split on rhizomes.
Habit: Height:  12", 24" with flowers Spread:  18" Clumping habit
Something Special or Unique: Native plant, excellent cut flower.

Soil Type: Well-draining; drought resistant
Habit: Height:  24” (36” with flower stalk) Spread:  12”-18” Clumping.
Something Special or Unique: There are separate male and female plants.  Male flowers are showier than the females.  Transplant seedlings in August, after the summer heat. Tolerates black walnut trees.

Soil Type: Any soil, do not overwater (turns yellow)
When to Divide: Prefers not to be divided, easy to make cuttings and soak in water to start new plants
Habit: Height: 6-8”, Spread: 8”, Clumping
Long Lived or Short Lived: Rejuvenate by starting new plants from cuttings, or by lifting plant sprigs and adding leafy compost underneath.  Sprigs will grow new roots and rejuvenate plant
Something Special or Unique: Excellent for chicken and beef or vegetable casseroles. Has a citrus aftertaste. Use three to four sprigs per recipe. Can also be used to make tea. Plant grown organically

Soil Type: Any soil, do not overwater (turns yellow)
When to Divide: Prefers not to be divided, easy to make cuttings and soak in water to start new plants
Habit: Height: 6-8”, Spread: 8”, Clumping
Long Lived or Short Lived: Rejuvenate by starting new plants from cuttings, or by lifting plant sprigs and adding leafy compost underneath.  Sprigs will grow new roots and rejuvenate plant
Something Special or Unique: Excellent for chicken and beef or vegetable casseroles.  Use three to four sprigs per recipe.  Can also be used to make tea.  Plant grown organically.

Soil Type: Will grow in average, medium soils, but prefers rich, humusy, moisture-retentive soils.  Ensure the soil is well-drained but does not dry out; wet soils in winter can be fatal.
When to Divide: Resents division.  Avoid transplant if possible.  It may spread by stolons to form clumps.
Habit: Height:  12" with flowers, Spread:  12-24", Clumping
Something Special or Unique: Remove the spikes after flowering to bring attention to the foliage mound.  Plant in forests on hillsides or moist areas along humusy stream banks.

Soil Type: Loamy, well-draining, average soil, will tolerates clay.  Does not tolerate water-logged soil in winter.
When to Divide: Do not divide; propagate by seed instead
Habit: Height:  24" Spread:  12"
Something Special or Unique: Native plant.  May wilt during drought, but will recover readily after rainfall.

Soil Type: Any soil
When to Divide: Can be transplanted when less than 1 foot tall
Habit: Height: 4-6', Spread: 12”, Clumping, spreading by rosettes, but after many years
Maturity Rate: Three years until full height, might bloom first year, but definitely second year
Long Lived or Short Lived: Small first year, spends most of its energy setting roots
Something Special or Unique: Very difficult to grow from seed. Prefers afternoon shade from sun. May sag in full heat of summer, but recovers in the evening the first two years.  Monarch magnet.  Does not come up until June.  Mark so as not to accidentally dig it up.

Soil Type: Any soil, well-drained
When to Divide: Divide rosettes in spring every third year.
Habit: Height:  36" Spread:  12"
Something Special or Unique: Good mildew resistance, good cut flower. Genus name honors Saint Veronica who reportedly gave a handkerchief to Jesus so he could wipe sweat from his face on the way to Calvary, with some genus plants having markings that resemble the markings on the sacred handkerchief

Soil Type: Well draining, drought tolerant
Habit: Height: 24”, Spread: 24”, Clumping
Maturity Rate: Second year, plants will show true leaf color
Something Special or Unique: Good mildew resistance, good cut flower. Genus name honors Saint Veronica who reportedly gave a handkerchief to Jesus so he could wipe sweat from his face on the way to Calvary, with some genus plants having markings that resemble the markings on the sacred handkerchief

Soil Type: Average, medium to wet, well-drained soils
Habit: Height: 3'-4', 7' when blooming; Spread: 2'-3', Erect
Maturity Rate: Blooms second year.  They will double in size each year until full growth has been achieved in the third year.
Something Special or Unique: Can deadhead spent flower stalks to extend bloom period.  New foliage growth can be stimulated by cutting back plants to basal growth.  This may also promote a late summer or fall bloom.  Native to Eastern North America.
